title: Sylvie Courvoisier Trio - Double Windsor (2014)
description:
Tzadik, Spectrum Series 2: TZ 4002 
http://www.tzadik.com/index.php?catalog=4002 
http://www.tzadik.com/volume.php?VolumeID=756 
http://www.sylviecourvoisier.com/fenetres/Double_Windsor.htm

* Sylvie Courvoisier: piano
* Drew Gress: bass
* Kenny Wollesen: drums
 
http://www.sylviecourvoisier.com/ 
http://www.drewgress.com/ 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenny_Wollesen

Recorded by Chris Allen at Sear Sound, New York on January 6th 2014.


Reviews
~~~~~~~

By Greg Buium 
http://www.pointofdeparture.org/PoD48/PoD48MomentsNotice.html

[...]

Double Windsor is a rich and exciting debut â€“ a just off-center, and
wonderfully fertile version of what a more orthodox piano trio might
be. Courvoisierâ€™s nine compositions fuel this idiosyncratic point of
view. Thereâ€™s the through-composed. Thereâ€™s material that straight away opens
up to improvisation. There are melodies in the jazz tradition and spare, barely
notated bits that fuel complete freedom.

Nothing stays still for long; thereâ€™s a lot of writing. The pieces are often
packed with jumpy lines and little detours (Courvoisier calls them
â€œinterruptionsâ€). The opener, and title piece, nearly contains it all: the
dense, driving pulse (an ostinato in 10/8), constant forward motion, tightly
wound figures, and a series of sections framed by improvisation. Each motif and
mood feels embedded in the overarching design, rather than â€“ again, in
conventional jazz parlance â€“ returning to a head.

This push and pull, this elastic relationship to time, form and drama seems
second nature to Gress and Wollesen. The little pathways between a line and an
improvisation arenâ€™t stitched: theyâ€™re an organic part of things. In other
hands, Courvoisierâ€™s music could easily feel overwritten â€“ as a lesser rhythm
section clunks toward another programmed bit. But it never does.

[...]

--
